verses.text: Do not be disturbed by evildoers; do not be envious of those who do wrong.
verses.comment: The call to avoid envy or anger towards the wicked is a frequent theme in wisdom literature (see Proverbs 24:19). Setting one's heart on God, not worldly success, is foundational for biblical righteousness woven throughout both Old and New Testaments.

verses.text: For they will soon wither like grass and fade like green plants.
verses.comment: The comparison to fading grass is reminiscent of Isaiah 40. The fleeting nature of worldly power is contrasted sharply with the permanence of God’s kingdom.

verses.text: Trust in the LORD and do good; dwell in the land and cultivate faithfulness.
verses.comment: There is a promise of security and inheritance for the faithful. Catholics see in this invitation to dwell and 'work the land' a foreshadowing of the life of virtue and the Church’s enduring presence.

verses.text: Delight yourself in the LORD, and He will give you the desires of your heart.
verses.comment: Spiritual delight in God aligns our desires with His will (cf. Psalm 145:19). Catholic tradition encourages the seeking of God Himself as the greatest desire of the heart.

verses.text: Commit your way to the LORD; trust in Him, and He will act.
verses.comment: Entrusting one’s life to God and allowing Him to guide has strong echoes in Christ’s teachings on abandonment to God’s will (see Matt 6:33).

verses.text: He will bring forth your righteousness as the light, and your justice as the noonday.
verses.comment: The vindication of the righteous is a central promise. Light as a symbol anticipates Christ (cf. John 8:12), the Light of the world.

verses.text: Be still before the LORD and wait patiently for Him; do not fret because of the one who prospers in his way, because of the man who carries out evil schemes.
verses.comment: Patience is emphasized, echoing both the virtue of hope and the contemplative stillness encouraged in Catholic spirituality.

verses.text: Refrain from anger and abandon wrath; do not fret—it leads only to evil.
verses.comment: The instruction to turn from anger is echoed in the teachings of Jesus (Matt 5:22). In Catholic tradition, anger is counted among the seven deadly sins.

verses.text: For evildoers will be cut off, but those who hope in the LORD will inherit the land.
verses.comment: ‘Inherit the land’ also prefigures Christ’s Beatitude on the meek (Matthew 5:5). Catholics see this as not only material but spiritual inheritance, pointing to the saints’ share in the heavenly Jerusalem.

verses.text: In just a little while, the wicked will be no more; though you look for them, they will not be found.
verses.comment: Echoes the prophetic perspective of God's ultimate justice.

verses.text: But the meek will inherit the land and will delight themselves in abundant peace.
verses.comment: Directly quoted by Christ in the Sermon on the Mount, showing fulfillment in the Church. Catholic commentary sees this as a pointer to the sanctity and ultimate reward of the humble (saints).

verses.text: The wicked plot against the righteous and gnash their teeth at him.
verses.comment: Gnashing of teeth becomes, in Jesus’ teaching, a sign of the torment of the damned (Matt 13:42).

verses.text: But the Lord laughs at the wicked, for He knows their day is coming.
verses.comment: Contrast between God’s sovereignty and human schemes. Related to divine providence and the ultimate futility of opposing God’s will.

verses.text: The wicked draw the sword and bend the bow to bring down the poor and needy, to kill those whose way is upright;
verses.comment: A warning of injustice. Christ, identifying with the poor and persecuted (see Matthew 25:40), fulfills this by His passion and death.

verses.text: but their sword will enter their own heart, and their bows will be broken.
verses.comment: The self-destruction of evil plots is a reversal theme common in both Psalms and Marian prayers (cf. Magnificat, Luke 1:51-53).

verses.text: Better is the little that the righteous has than the abundance of many wicked.
verses.comment: Echoes the theme that true riches are spiritual, not material—see Jesus’ teaching on treasures in heaven (Luke 12:33).

verses.text: For the arms of the wicked will be broken, but the LORD upholds the righteous.
verses.comment: God’s active support for the righteous is a recurring promise in Psalms.

verses.text: The LORD knows the days of the blameless, and their inheritance will last forever.
verses.comment: Catholic interpreters see in this the security of the saints, preserved in grace, and the promise of eternal life.

verses.text: They are not put to shame in evil times; in the days of famine they have abundance.
verses.comment: God’s providence, both material and spiritual, is reaffirmed.

verses.text: But the wicked will perish; the enemies of the LORD will vanish like smoke—like the splendor of pastures, they disappear.
verses.comment: Fleeting glory of the wicked is contrasted with the enduring reward of the righteous.

verses.text: The wicked borrows and does not pay back, but the righteous is generous and gives.
verses.comment: Generosity is a mark of the just. Catholic social teaching takes its cue from such passages, emphasizing charity as integral to holiness.

verses.text: For those blessed by the LORD will inherit the land, but those cursed by Him will be cut off.
verses.comment: Inheritance through blessing foreshadows the Gospel theme of beatitude. See also the Church's emphasis on the efficacy of blessing (sacramentals).

verses.text: The steps of a man are established by the LORD when He delights in his way.
verses.comment: God's guidance is both providential and personal. In Catholic spirituality, this verse resonates with the idea of discernment and vocation.

verses.text: Though he falls, he will not be cast headlong, for the LORD upholds his hand.
verses.comment: God’s mercy aids the just when they stumble, hinting at the Church’s teaching on grace sustaining us after sin (see Sacrament of Reconciliation).

verses.text: I was young and now am old, yet I have not seen the righteous forsaken or his children begging for bread.
verses.comment: God’s faithfulness to generations is celebrated—seen in the Catholic Church’s stress on family and spiritual heritage.

verses.text: He is always generous and lends freely; his children are blessed.
verses.comment: Children inheriting blessing for a parent’s virtue echoes Catholic teachings on the communion of saints and intergenerational blessing.

verses.text: Turn away from evil and do good, so you will dwell forever.
verses.comment: Holiness of life ensures lasting security—a principle undergirding Christ’s call to discipleship (Mark 10:21).

verses.text: For the LORD loves justice; He will not abandon His saints. They are preserved forever, but the children of the wicked will be cut off.
verses.comment: God’s love for justice underlies Catholic teaching on the communion of saints and final perseverance (see Jude 1:24).

verses.text: The righteous will inherit the land and dwell upon it forever.
verses.comment: An eternal inheritance points to the New Covenant hope—fulfilled in Christ offering the Church both here and in eternity.

verses.text: The mouth of the righteous utters wisdom, and his tongue speaks what is just.
verses.comment: The speech of the virtuous reflects the wisdom of the Holy Spirit—a theme expanded upon in the New Testament (James 3:13).

verses.text: The law of his God is in his heart; his steps do not slip.
verses.comment: ‘Law written on the heart’ is fulfilled in the New Covenant (cf. Jer. 31:33), which the Catholic Church holds as inaugurated through Christ and entered in Baptism.

verses.text: The wicked watches for the righteous and seeks to put him to death.
verses.comment: A foreshadowing of Christ's passion: ‘they watched for his life’ (see Mark 14:1; John 7:1).

verses.text: The LORD will not abandon him to his power or let him be condemned when he is judged.
verses.comment: Echoes the resurrection—evil does not have the last word. Note the Catholic view of God’s continuing deliverance through grace.

verses.text: Wait for the LORD and keep His way, and He will exalt you to inherit the land; you will look on when the wicked are cut off.
verses.comment: Waiting and perseverance are rewarded. Catholic tradition encourages perseverance in faith, especially in hardships.

verses.text: I have seen a wicked, ruthless man, spreading himself like a green tree in its native soil.
verses.comment: The image of seeming prosperity is ultimately deceptive, as the next verse shows.

verses.text: But he passed away, and behold, he was no more; though I sought him, he could not be found.
verses.comment: The visible success of the wicked has no permanence—an encouragement to trust in God’s justice.

verses.text: Mark the blameless person, and observe the upright, for there is a future for the man of peace.
verses.comment: The promise of peace and a future ties into Christ's blessing of peacemakers (see Matthew 5:9).

verses.text: But transgressors will be destroyed together; the future of the wicked will be cut off.
verses.comment: Clear statement of final judgment. Catholic doctrine stresses the reality of both heaven and hell.

verses.text: The salvation of the righteous comes from the LORD; He is their stronghold in the time of trouble.
verses.comment: Old Testament salvation prefigures Christ, who Christians view as true Deliverer and refuge for the Church.

verses.text: The LORD helps them and delivers them; He delivers them from the wicked and saves them, because they take refuge in Him.
verses.comment: Taking refuge in God points ahead to the Church as the ark of salvation, a motif carried into Catholic understanding of the role of the Church and the sacraments as means of grace.
